text: Ok, I've taken a look, but  I notice there is a requirement of derivatives in the loss function. Are these realised by autodiff rather than finite differences then?

elements.text: Ok, I've taken a look, but  I notice there is a requirement of derivatives in the loss function. Are these realised by autodiff rather than finite differences then?

text: Is the performance of such models state of the art for PDEs? If not what are the use cases for which they excel?

elements.text: Is the performance of such models state of the art for PDEs? If not what are the use cases for which they excel?

text: Ok I think I just now understood how powerful and general SciML is, any function that you can write no matter the complexity can be used as the loss and a fast model can be found by nature of neural nets being universal approximators - extremely useful and cool
